reviewText: Amusing slapstick mystery-comedy with Ole Olsen and Chic Johnson, who are an acquired taste.  Sort of a remake of Abbott and Costello's Hold That Ghost.  A Southern colonel and his two daughters move into a creaky old house where weird things start happening.  Olsen and Johnson trip along to try to help solve the haunting.  I ordered this movie through Amazon and received a DVD-R produced by Loving the Classics.  The quality is poor and the DVD-R at one point glitches and freezes.  I hope that this film is  cleaned up and re-mastered so it can be released professionally.
Title: N/A

reviewText: One of the things often overlooked in Ghost Catchers and Crazy House is the great music.  Both movies have some really great talent playing and singing some rarely heard songs.  It's a real shame these movies were never released by Universal and given the treatment they deserve.  We have to make do with the VHS and these DVD-R productions as they are all that is available.  I think these were recorded from TV broadcasts - and are now in the public domain.Kirby Grant of Sky King fame and numerous "B" westerns shows his real roots in Ghost Catchers.  The Kirby Grant Orchestra is featured with Kirby on violin and showing off his beautiful tenor voice.  Of special note is Gloria Jean - a beauty with a voice to match.  Another beautiful girl singer in Ghost Catchers is Martha O'Driscoll. The music makes this a very memorable film even if you don't like the screenplay. Personally, I like both...You may recognize many other actors in the movie, Lon Chaney, Andy Devine, Leo Carrillo (Pancho from the Cisco Kid), Ella May Morse, Walter Catlett, Morton Downey Sr. and others.One other thing, there is some great jitterbug dancing if that interests you.
summary: Very Good Movie and Some Great Music
Title: N/A

reviewText: When a refined(?) Southern gentleman and his two lovely daughters rent a house in New York, no one bothers to tell them that it just might be haunted.  When they hear strange noises they go next door for help, and get more than they bargained for when the help turns out to be Ole Olsen and Chic Johnson.These two lead a merry madcap hunt for the ghost and attempt to drive him out of the house.  They find that there's a little more to the house than they had thought, which causes their momentary incarceration, followed by their hilarious escape, followed by the almost mandatory chase scene.It's a load of laughs and well worth the cost, but please remember, it's black and white and the sound is in glorious schizophrenic orthopedic monaural.  Still, if you want an hour and a half of classic vaudeville and slapstick, then "Ghost Catchers" is definitely your cup of whatever.
Title: N/A

reviewText: The team of Ole Olsen and Chic Johnson probably made their best films at Universal. At the very least, they came the closest to the boys' concept of insane humor, a willingness to try anything for a laugh. Hot on the heels of "Crazy House" comes "Ghost Catchers", arguably among the best (they made one more, "See My Lawyer", which was hardly worth the effort, then returned to stage work) of their short list of films.The story involves a Southern colonel and his two daughters inheriting a mansion which, of course, turns out to be haunted. The strange noises get so that one daughter seeks help next door at a nightclub. Guess who's running it? O & J run what has to be the craziest, most bizarre stage show ever. After being abducted & made part of the act, the daughter explains her presence; the boys dutifully investigate the mansion in an all-night stay that introduces some pretty offbeat moments, as well as characters. Things are not what they seem, of course, and before they know it, the boys are involved in a tale of thugs (disguised as bears, horses, elves, etc.) trying to scare the occupants away. But true to O & J's peculiar style, there's tap-dancing ghosts (who pinch pretty girls) and magical clothes changes (my fave moment) before the story is resolved. While GC is not as crammed full of gags & energy as, say, "Crazy House", it still satisfies with the menacing atmosphere mixed with unusual gags. Director Edward Cline returns to guide the story, and does a fine job, thanks to him.So why just four stars? The problem isn't with the movie itself, but with the DVD transfer. The first half is marred by noisy static which nearly ruins the dialogue. Otherwise, this is an entertaining comedy from two lesser-known comics who really knew how to go all out.
summary: Who you gonna call? Olsen and Johnson!

reviewText: Buyer Beware! This is a bootleg DVD. It is copied from a Bootleg VHS, and has horrible picture and sound quality. The VHS  is not properly tracked during the transfer and the sound is muffled. The person selling these copies is in breech of the copyright holder and should be made accountable.As for the film, not everyone's cup of tea, but I thinks it's great.COME ON Universal release the O&J; films!!
Title: N/A

reviewText: The quality of the print is absolutely unacceptable - worse than a poor VHS; but more unacceptable was the sound: I couldn't get rid of the annoying hum no matter how much I fiddled with my audio controls. It's been ages since I've purchased a film of this inferior quality; I've purchased countless of classic and vintage films, but none since a few VHS' purchased in the 1980s that were this bad. I'm highly disappointed and if it weren't for the moderately low cost and time I've already wasted writing this review, I'd petition for a full refund. I'm throwing this DVD in the garbage - I have no use for it.  The film itself has funny moments, but not my cup of tea, not refined enough.  I do think this comedy team had great potential: this entry lacked in script and scenes.
Title: N/A
